title: Croucher-2023
text:
These notes contain lessons on the following topics:

Lesson 1 an introduction to species distribution modelling,
Lesson 2 using Bayesian statistical modelling,
Lesson 3 machine learning for species distribution modelling, and
Lesson 4 an introduction to using the Darwin system for ecosystem modelling.

The resources page contains links to data sources and relevant papers.

title: About
text: All the notes for this mini-course are on GitHub in the project AndrewIrwin/croucher-2023.

title: About
section: About the author and course instructor
text:
About the author and course instructor
These course notes were written by Andrew Irwin (Department of Mathematics & Statistics at Dalhousie University in Halifax, Nova Scotia, Canada). Andrew’s research applies mathematical and statistical models to problems in biological oceanography, particularly questions about phytoplankton biogeography, productivity, and their role in biogeochemical cycles. The prospect of large-scale systemic change over the next century plays a key motivating role in the desire to understand this important system more fully. Andrew co-directs the Marine Microbial Macroecology Lab at Dalhousie and more information about his research can be found there.

title: Resources
text:
Data for this mini-course are in the GitHub repository in the folder data. Sources are described below.


The CARIACO project was a 22 year (1995-2017) project based off the coast of Venezuela.

Compilation of phytoplankton and zooplankton abundance from Station CARIACO. Total biomass and counts of 30-60 zooplankton types from 153 monthly samples. BCO-DMO.




Darwin is a marine ecosystem/biogeochemical/optical model that is part of the MITgcm. The simulation reported here includes 50 plankton types spanning a number of functional types and size classes, following Follett et al (2022). The simulation was global on a coarse (1 degree lat/long) grid using realistic 3D physical fields (Wunch and Heimbach, 2007). It was run for 10 “generic” years and output provided here are from the 10th year (monthly averages). I have simplified the output considerably; the full output can be found at the links below.

Darwin + MITgcm computer code. Model code: Darwin3 (see pkg/darwin) Documentation. Code browser + search
Dukiewicz, Stephanie (2021) Darwin3 31+16+3 model output: annual mean surface plankton biomass. Harvard Dataverse. 10.7910/DVN/FEWXB4
Dutkiewicz, Stephanie; Jahn, Oliver. (2021) Darwin3 31+16+3 model code, datafiles and parameters. Harvard Dataverse. 10.7910/DVN/ISJQ1W

title: Species distribution models
text:
The CARIACO project (Carbon Retention in a Colored Ocean) ran for about 20 years from 1997-2017. Samples were collected in most months, with an increasing number of gaps near the end of the project. A primary goal of the project was to better understand carbon export in this part of the ocean which is notable for its well preserved and laminated sediments. Here we will use the samples of phytoplankton and zooplankton from the upper mixed layer.
Data are arcived on BCO-DMO. A subset of the data we will use is in the github project.
